H0.text: Stars are the bodies in which the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen is constantly increasing in the universe.

H1.text: Planets are the bodies in which the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen is constantly increasing in the universe.

H2.text: Galaxies are the bodies in which the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen is constantly increasing in the universe.

H3.text: Solar systems are the bodies in which the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen is constantly increasing in the universe.

A4.text: However, this does not by itself significantly alter the abundances of elements in the universe as the elements are contained within the star.

A6.text: Electron capture in very dense parts of the infalling matter may produce additional neutrons. Because some of the rebounding matter is bombarded by the neutrons, some of its nuclei capture them, creating a spectrum of heavier-than-iron material including the radioactive elements up to (and likely beyond) uranium.

A7.text: At the end of helium fusion, the core of a star consists primarily of carbon and oxygen.
